Normally, if I plan to castle, my B will be defended, and his won't. So the opposite fianchettoes - as a general principle - are stronger when the K is castled and the B defended. Otherwise, they can be a weakness.
Finally I "saw" that this move was dued, but now maybe now. Anyway, white was too shy in not taking advantage of e4 at once, and I had to put something in the way.
